title: Pacman Frog Heating & Lighting Guide: UVB, Thermostats & Equipment
description: Complete heating and lighting guide for Pacman frogs including heat lamp selection, UVB recommendations, thermostat types, and the science behind overhead heating.
author: Habitat Builder
excerpt: Evidence-based guide to heating and lighting for Pacman frogs: why overhead heating is best, UVB benefits, thermostat selection, and complete equipment recommendations.

content.heading: Why Proper Heating and Lighting Matters
content.text: Even though Pacman frogs are nocturnal and don't bask like bearded dragons, they still benefit tremendously from overhead heating and UVB lighting. Science shows that heat lamps providing short wavelength infrared radiation improve digestion, immune function, and overall health. This guide explains the evidence and helps you choose the right equipment.

content.heading: The Science: Short vs Long Wavelength Infrared

content.text: Not all heat is created equal. Different heat sources produce different types of infrared radiation:

Short Wavelength Infrared (Infrared-A): Produced by the sun, halogen bulbs, and incandescent bulbs. Penetrates deep into body tissues for effective warming. Improves digestion, immune function, and tissue health.

Long Wavelength Infrared (Infrared-C): Produced by heat mats, ceramic heat emitters (CHEs), and deep heat projectors (DHPs). Only warms surface tissues. Less effective for core body temperature and digestion.
OVERHEAD HEATING PREFERRED - Heat lamps provide short wavelength IR that penetrates tissues for better digestion. Heat mats/CHEs/DHPs provide long wavelength IR (less effective for health).
The best daytime heat source for Pacman frogs is a white halogen or incandescent flood bulb:
Why white light bulbs:

items: Produce beneficial short wavelength infrared (IR-A)
Most closely imitate natural sunlight
Improve digestion and nutrient absorption
Support healthy immune function
Create natural day/night cycle
Much dimmer than actual sunlight (even albinos usually tolerate them)

content.text: Recommended bulb types:

items: Halogen Flood Bulbs: Hardware store bulbs, 20-60w typical range, very affordable ($3-8 each)
Incandescent Flood Bulbs: Increasingly rare due to regulations, 25-75w typical, excellent heat quality
Pet Store "Basking" Bulbs: Same as above but marked up ($10-15), not necessary unless convenient

content.text: Wattage selection:
Start with 20-40w for most setups. Factors affecting wattage needed:

items: Enclosure size (larger = more watts)
Room temperature (colder room = more watts)
Enclosure height (taller = more watts for same substrate temperature)
Screen vs glass top (screen loses more heat)
Time of year (winter needs more heat than summer)

content.text: If 40w isn't enough, try 50-60w. If too hot even with dimmer, go lower wattage.
Albino Pacman frogs may be more light-sensitive, but most tolerate low-wattage heat lamps (20-40w) without issues. These bulbs are FAR dimmer than sunlight.
If your albino frog shows discomfort with heat lamps:

items: Add overhead vines and foliage to break up lighting
Try lower wattage (20-25w)
As last resort, use DHP (loses short wavelength IR benefits)

content.text: ALWAYS try heat lamps first before switching to DHP.
Most Pacman frogs do fine with nighttime temperatures down to ~65°F (18°C). Supplemental night heat usually not needed.
If night heating required (room drops below 65°F):
Option 1: Deep Heat Projector (DHP)

items: Produces long wavelength IR without light
More effective than CHE or heat mat
Projects heat downward like sun
Requires dimming thermostat
Arcadia and Pangea make quality DHPs

content.text: Option 2: Ceramic Heat Emitter (CHE)

items: Produces long wavelength IR without light
Less effective than DHP
Affordable ($15-25)
Can use on-off or pulse-proportional thermostat
Long-lasting (1-2 years typical)

content.text: Option 3: Heat Mat

items: Belly heat (not ideal but functional)
Use on SIDE of enclosure, not bottom (risk of dehydration)
Can use on-off thermostat
Cover only 1/3 of one side
Least effective option but most affordable

content.text: NIGHTTIME DARKNESS REQUIRED - Do NOT use blue/red/purple 'moonlight' bulbs. Frogs can see these lights just fine. Use total darkness for healthy circadian rhythm. See explanation by exotic vet Dr. Diehl.

rows: Under heat lamp, measure at substrate surface

content.text: Use infrared temperature gun to measure substrate surface temperature under heat lamp. This is where frog will experience warmth.
Heat lamps and DHPs MUST be controlled by thermostats. Two thermostat types exist:

content.heading: Dimming Thermostats (BEST for Heat Lamps & DHPs)

content.text: Dimming thermostats control the amount of power sent to heat source. When probe gets too hot, dimmer reduces power. When too cold, increases power.
Why dimming is essential for heat lamps:

items: Prevents flashing lights (disturbs circadian rhythm)
Extends bulb life dramatically
Provides smooth temperature control
Maintains stable environment
Worth the investment for animal health

content.text: Budget Dimming Options:

items: Exo Terra 600w Electronic Thermostat: $50-70, basic dimming mode, good entry option

content.text: Professional Grade Dimmers:

items: Herpstat 1-Basic or higher: $100-200+, excellent quality, many features
Vivarium Electronics VE-200: $80-100, reliable dimming
Vivarium Electronics VE-300: $120-150, dual output (day and night heat)
Vivarium Electronics VE-300X2: $180-220, two independent channels

content.text: DIMMER THERMOSTATS REQUIRED - Heat lamps and DHPs need dimming thermostats (not on/off). Flashing disrupts circadian rhythm and causes premature bulb failure. Use manual dimmer + on/off thermostat backup if budget-limited.

content.heading: Budget Alternative: Manual Dimmer + On/Off Thermostat

content.text: If dimming thermostat is unaffordable, use this workaround:

items: Buy dimmable lamp fixture with built-in dimmer switch ($15-30)
Manually adjust dimmer until correct temperature achieved
Add on-off thermostat as emergency backup to prevent overheating
On-off thermostat should rarely trigger if dimmer set correctly

content.text: Dimmable lamp fixtures:

items: Fluker's Repta-Clamp Lamp with Dimmer Switch ($20-30)
Hardware store dimmer-equipped clamp lamps

content.text: Budget on/off thermostats:

items: BN-Link Thermostat ($15-25)
Inkbird ITC-308 ($30-40)

content.heading: On/Off Thermostats (ONLY for CHEs & Heat Mats)

content.text: CHEs and heat mats can safely use cheaper on-off or pulse-proportional thermostats:

items: BN-Link Thermostat ($15-25)
Inkbird ITC-308 ($30-40)
Zoo Med ReptiTemp ($35-50)

content.text: These toggle power on/off to maintain temperature. Acceptable for non-light heat sources.

items: Place probe on warm side of enclosure
At substrate level (where frog experiences temperature)
Under decorations or secured to glass (prevent frog from moving it)
Away from direct heat lamp beam (measures air/substrate temp, not lamp output)
Keep probe clean and functional

content.text: UVB lighting allows Pacman frogs to synthesize vitamin D3 in their skin for calcium metabolism. Traditionally not provided, but research shows significant health benefits.
Benefits of UVB:

items: Natural vitamin D3 synthesis (reduces supplement dependency)
Improved calcium metabolism (prevents MBD)
Enhanced immune function
More natural circadian rhythm regulation
Behavioral enrichment (can sense UV wavelengths)
Mimics natural habitat (even nocturnal species exposed to UV during day)

content.text: UVB is NOT required for survival but is HIGHLY RECOMMENDED for optimal health. Think of it like taking multivitamins - you can survive without them, but you're healthier with them.
Recommended UVB strength: 5.0 or 6% (forest/tropical species strength)
Target coverage: 50% of enclosure length
Picking appropriate UVB is complex and depends on:

items: Enclosure dimensions (length, width, height)
Distance between bulb and substrate surface
Whether frog is albino (lower UVI needed)
Screen blocking UVB (removes ~30-50%)
Bulb output and brand variations

content.text: For detailed UVB bulb recommendations specific to your enclosure, please post on r/pacmanfrogs with:

items: Enclosure dimensions (L×W×H in inches)
Distance from lid to substrate surface
Whether frog is albino
Type of enclosure top (screen vs solid)

content.text: Community members will recommend specific bulb and fixture for your setup.
General UVB options:

items: T5 HO Linear Fixtures: Most effective, even UVB spread, best for 18"+ enclosures (Arcadia, Zoo Med)
T8 Linear Fixtures: Weaker output, need closer placement, budget option
Compact Fluorescent (NOT coils): Some models acceptable for small enclosures, avoid traditional coil bulbs

content.text: For extensive UVB science and research, see our Comprehensive UVB Guide.
NEVER USE: Coil UVB bulbs (uneven spread), Mercury Vapor bulbs (too hot), LED UVA/UVB combo bulbs (produce dangerous UVC radiation causing skin/eye injury).

items: Extremely uneven UVB distribution (hot spots and dead zones)
Difficult for frog to get proper UVB exposure
Poor coverage area
Frequently fail quality control
Short effective lifespan
Produce EXTREME heat (150-250w typical)
Produce EXTREME UVB output (desert-level)
Cannot be controlled with thermostats
Will overheat and burn Pacman frogs
Only suitable for large desert reptile enclosures (6+ feet)

content.heading: Why NOT LED UVA/UVB Combo Bulbs

content.text: LED UVA/UVB bulbs are EXTREMELY DANGEROUS despite marketing claims:

items: Produce UVC radiation (most harmful UV, causes skin and eye damage)
Produce unnaturally high UVB levels even after months of use
High UVI persists even through mesh screens
Risk of permanent eye damage and skin injury
Claims of safety are FALSE - independent testing shows danger

content.text: UVB bulbs lose output over time even though they still produce visible light:
Mark replacement date on calendar when installing new bulb.
Maintain consistent 12-hour day/night cycle. Use timer for automation ($10-15).
Daytime Heating (Required):

items: Halogen or incandescent flood bulb (20-60w, start with 40w)
Dome lamp fixture with ceramic socket (rated for bulb wattage)
Dimming thermostat OR dimmable fixture + on-off thermostat
Infrared temperature gun ($15-25)

content.text: Nighttime Heating (If Room < 65°F):

items: DHP OR CHE OR heat mat
Second dome fixture if using DHP/CHE
On-off thermostat for CHE/heat mat (can use same dimmer if using DHP)

content.text: UVB (Optional but Recommended):

items: T5 HO or T8 linear fixture (length based on enclosure)
5.0 or 6% UVB bulb (appropriate length)
Fixture mounting hardware or legs
Timer for automation

content.text: Monitoring:

items: 2 digital thermometers with probes (warm and cool side)
2 digital hygrometers with probes (warm and cool side)
Infrared temperature gun for spot checking

rows: Heat lamp, manual dimmer fixture, on-off thermostat, thermometers
Above + T5 HO UVB fixture and bulb, timer
Above + Herpstat dimming thermostat, DHP for night heat, quality fixtures

items: Using heat mats instead of overhead heating (loses IR-A benefits)
No thermostat (overheating or underheating)
Using on-off thermostat with heat lamp (flashing light)
Coil UVB bulbs (uneven output)
Mercury vapor bulbs (too hot, too strong)
LED UVB bulbs (dangerous UVC production)
Blue/red night lights (frogs can see them)
No UVB provided at all (missing health benefits)
Forgetting to replace UVB bulbs yearly
Thermostat probe in wrong location (inaccurate temps)
